reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: TEH UNODC crime prevention criminal just

description.narrative: UNODC Iran has implemented a number of rule of law projects in (I.R. of) Iran including: (i) Strengthening judicial capacity; (ii) Promoting the reform process of the judiciary and prison system; (iii) Improving of public access to legal information, through the establishment of a pilot e-court in Tehran and a telephone-based and audio-legal post providing free legal advice; and (iv) Improving of Iranian legislative and judicial capacity to tackle organized crimes and money-laundering and promoting mutual legal assistance. The present project proposal is part of the UNODC Country Partnership Programme (2015-2019) in (I.R. of) Iran, signed on 15th December 2015, between the UNODC Executive Director and the Iranian Minister of Interior. This Programme has been developed through a participatory process with the national authorities of (I.R. of) Iran, and in consultation with the members of the Mini-Dublin Group in Tehran. As regards Sub-Programme 2 on “Crime, Corruption and Criminal Justice” of the Country Partnership Programme, the objectives set out received support from and endorsement by the Head of the Iranian Judiciary. UNODC strives to ensure that a gender balanced perspective is mainstreamed in all its practices, policies and activities. In this context, the UNODC Iran Country Partnership Programme ensures that all activities are implemented in line with the United Nations gender related policies. UNODC Iran will continue to use its presence and contacts with the national counterparts to draw attention to the relevant international standards on human rights and to maintain the highest level dialogue with the Iranian authorities on a moratorium on capital punishment for drug-related criminal offences, with a view to complete abolition. UNODC Iran will support and encourage the active involvement and participation of the civil society and NGOs in (I.R. of) Iran, including to seek the participation of other relevant NGOs (such as from the Netherlands and others), in the implementation of the planned project activities. Finally, the implementation of the present proposal will further contribute to the overall objective of Sub-Programme 2 on “Crime, C orruption and Criminal Justice”, which aims at providing technical assistance and legislative support to Iranian judicial (including the justice and prisons system personnel, courts, and members of bar associations) through familiarizations of the national counter parts with the international standards and good practices, especially on internationally recognized human rights norms. The project activities would focus in particular on areas related to pre-trial, case management, investigation, prosecution, restorative justice and legal aid.
